title: The Organon (The Instrument)
summary: Aristotle's six foundational works on logic that created the discipline and provided the tools for scientific reasoning for 2000 years.
context: Aristotle developed his logical system as the essential 'instrument' (organon) for all philosophical and scientific inquiry. These works established the principles of valid reasoning that dominated Western thought until the 19th century.

works.title: Categories
works.abstract: Identifies ten fundamental ways things can be predicated: Substance, Quantity, Quality, Relation, Place, Time, Position, State, Action, and Affection.
works.keyQuote: "Substance, in the truest and primary sense, is that which is neither predicable of a subject nor present in a subject."
works.impact:
‚Ä¢ Foundation for ontology and metaphysics
‚Ä¢ Influenced medieval philosophy and linguistics
‚Ä¢ Basis for classification systems

works.title: On Interpretation
works.abstract: Analyzes propositions, truth values, and the relationship between language, thought, and reality.
works.keyQuote: "To say of what is that it is not, or of what is not that it is, is false."
works.impact:
‚Ä¢ Developed square of opposition
‚Ä¢ Addressed future contingents problem
‚Ä¢ Foundation for philosophy of language

works.title: Prior Analytics
works.abstract: Presents the theory of the syllogism - the first formal system of deductive reasoning.
works.keyQuote: "A syllogism is discourse in which, certain things being stated, something other than what is stated follows of necessity."
works.impact:
‚Ä¢ Invented formal logic
‚Ä¢ Dominated logic for 2000 years
‚Ä¢ Basis for scientific demonstration

works.title: Posterior Analytics
works.abstract: Explains how we gain certain knowledge through demonstration from first principles.
works.keyQuote: "We think we understand a thing when we know its cause."
works.impact:
‚Ä¢ Model for scientific method
‚Ä¢ Inspired Euclidean geometry
‚Ä¢ Foundation for epistemology

works.title: Topics
works.abstract: Provides methods for argumentation based on generally accepted opinions rather than certain premises.
works.keyQuote: "Dialectic is a process of criticism wherein lies the path to the principles of all inquiries."
works.impact:
‚Ä¢ Art of philosophical debate
‚Ä¢ Foundation for rhetoric
‚Ä¢ Method for exploring difficult questions

works.title: On Sophistical Refutations
works.abstract: Classifies and analyzes logical fallacies used in deceptive arguments.
works.keyQuote: "Some arguments are dialectical and others sophistical."
works.impact:
‚Ä¢ First systematic study of fallacies
‚Ä¢ Critical thinking tool
‚Ä¢ Protection against deceptive arguments

title: The Natural Sciences Corpus
summary: Aristotle's massive research program investigating the natural world through observation, classification, and teleological explanation.
context: Aristotle established the first research institute (the Lyceum) where he and his students systematically investigated all aspects of nature. They collected specimens, conducted dissections, and observed phenomena across the Greek world.

majorWorks.title: Physics
majorWorks.abstract: Investigates the fundamental principles of natural objects: matter, form, change, motion, time, and place.
majorWorks.keyDiscovery: Everything in nature has four causes: material, formal, efficient, and final
majorWorks.impact:
‚Ä¢ Foundation of natural philosophy for 2000 years
‚Ä¢ Teleological view of nature
‚Ä¢ Rejection of atomism and vacuum

majorWorks.title: On the Heavens
majorWorks.abstract: Describes the structure of the universe, celestial bodies, and the elements.
majorWorks.keyDiscovery: Elements move toward natural places: earth (down), fire (up), air and water (intermediate)
majorWorks.impact:
‚Ä¢ Geocentric cosmology
‚Ä¢ Quintessence (fifth element)
‚Ä¢ Finite universe theory

majorWorks.title: On Generation and Corruption
majorWorks.abstract: Analyzes substantial change, mixture, and the transformation of elements.
majorWorks.keyDiscovery: All physical objects are compounds of matter (hyle) and form (morphe)
majorWorks.impact:
‚Ä¢ Theory of chemical change
‚Ä¢ Rejection of atomism
‚Ä¢ Basis for medieval alchemy

majorWorks.title: Meteorology
majorWorks.abstract: Studies atmospheric phenomena, geology, oceans, and weather.
majorWorks.keyDiscovery: Earthly phenomena operate differently from celestial realms
majorWorks.impact:
‚Ä¢ First systematic meteorology
‚Ä¢ Theories of earthquakes, comets, rainbows
‚Ä¢ Influenced medieval earth sciences

majorWorks.title: History of Animals
majorWorks.abstract: Massive compilation of observations on animal anatomy, behavior, and classification.
majorWorks.keyDiscovery: Systematic observation and classification of over 500 species
majorWorks.impact:
‚Ä¢ Foundation of zoology
‚Ä¢ Comparative anatomy
‚Ä¢ Biological classification

majorWorks.title: Parts of Animals
majorWorks.abstract: Explains animal structures through their functions and purposes.
majorWorks.keyDiscovery: "Nature does nothing in vain" - all parts serve functions
majorWorks.impact:

‚Ä¢ Comparative method
‚Ä¢ Rejection of random evolution

majorWorks.title: Generation of Animals
majorWorks.abstract: Studies animal reproduction, heredity, and embryonic development.
majorWorks.keyDiscovery: Male provides form (semen), female provides matter (menstrual blood)
majorWorks.impact:
‚Ä¢ Theory of reproduction for 2000 years
‚Ä¢ Embryology
‚Ä¢ Heredity theories

title: Metaphysics (First Philosophy)
summary: Aristotle's investigation into being as being, substance, causality, and the fundamental principles of reality - his most profound and difficult work.
context: Aristotle called this work 'First Philosophy' - the study of the most fundamental aspects of reality. The title 'Metaphysics' (meaning 'after the Physics') was given by later editors who placed it after his physical works.
abstract: Metaphysics studies existence itself - being qua being. It investigates substance, form, matter, potentiality, actuality, and the first causes of all things. The work culminates in the theory of the Unmoved Mover.

keyDoctrines.explanation: Metaphysics studies what it means for anything to exist, not just particular kinds of beings
keyDoctrines.keyQuote: "There is a science which investigates being as being and the attributes which belong to this in virtue of its own nature."

keyDoctrines.explanation: Complete understanding requires knowing: Material (what it's made of), Formal (its essence), Efficient (what made it), Final (its purpose)
keyDoctrines.keyQuote: "We do not have knowledge of a thing until we have grasped its 'why', that is, its cause."

keyDoctrines.explanation: Primary substances are individual things (this man, this horse) that exist independently. All other categories depend on substance.
keyDoctrines.keyQuote: "Substance is that which is neither predicable of a subject nor present in a subject."

keyDoctrines.explanation: Everything contains potentiality (what it can become) and actuality (what it currently is). Actuality is prior to potentiality.
keyDoctrines.keyQuote: "The actuality is the end, and it is for the sake of this that the potentiality is acquired."

keyDoctrines.explanation: There must be a first cause - eternal, immaterial, purely actual - that moves everything as a final cause by being an object of thought and desire.
keyDoctrines.keyQuote: "The final cause, then, produces motion as being loved, but all other things move by being moved."

critiqueOfPlato:
Aristotle systematically criticizes Plato's Theory of Forms:

**Third Man Argument**: If Forms exist because particulars share qualities, there must be higher Forms for what Forms and particulars share, leading to infinite regress.

**Separation Problem**: Forms separated from particulars cannot explain them.

**Knowledge Problem**: How can we know separate Forms through sense experience?

Aristotle's solution: Forms exist IN particular things, not separately.

‚Ä¢ Inspired cosmological arguments for God's existence

title: The Practical Philosophy Trilogy
summary: Aristotle's comprehensive system of practical philosophy covering ethics, politics, and economics - how humans should live individually and collectively.
context: While Aristotle's theoretical philosophy studied what is, his practical philosophy studied what should be - how humans can achieve eudaimonia (flourishing) through virtuous living in political communities.

theTrilogy.centralQuestion: What is the good life for a human being?
theTrilogy.answer: Eudaimonia achieved through virtuous activity in accordance with reason

theTrilogy.centralQuestion: What is the best political community?
theTrilogy.answer: A polis that enables citizens to live virtuous, flourishing lives
Through proper management of resources and relationships for the good life

integration:
These three works form an integrated system:

**Ethics ‚Üí Politics ‚Üí Economics**

Individual virtue requires the right political community, which depends on properly managed households. All aim at human flourishing.
